current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To improve outcomes for students in persistently
		  low-performing schools, to create a culture of recognizing, rewarding, and
		  replicating educational excellence, to authorize school turnaround grants, and
		  for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail:
introduced
			 the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Health, Education, Labor,
			 and Pensions

short-title.#text:
School Turnaround and Rewards Act
			 of 2013

text.#text:
This Act may be cited as
			 the
The purposes of this Act are to—

significantly
			 improve outcomes for students in persistently low-performing schools by—

building the
			 capacity of State educational agencies and local educational agencies to
			 improve student academic achievement in low-performing and persistently
			 low-performing schools;

targeting State
			 and local supports and strategies on the persistently lowest-performing schools
			 in each State; and

create a culture
			 of recognizing, rewarding, and replicating educational excellence in every
			 State by—

providing
			 financial and other incentives and rewards to schools that are identified as
			 Reward Schools; and

supporting State
			 educational agency efforts to identify, collect, and disseminate effective
			 practices for increasing student academic achievement used by Reward
			 Schools.

improve student achievement; and

Section 1116 of the
			 Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:1116

text.#text:
Each State receiving a grant under this
				part shall, beginning in the 2013–2014 school year and every year thereafter,
				determine the lowest-achieving schools in the State, which shall
				include—

the lowest-achieving 5 percent of public
				high schools, and the lowest-achieving 5 percent of public elementary schools
				and secondary schools that are not high schools, in the State, based on—

in the case of high schools, graduation
				rates; and
if the State so chooses—
schoolwide gains; and
absolute student performance; and

the public high schools in the State that
				have less than a 60-percent graduation rate.

In identifying the lowest-achieving schools
				under this paragraph, a State shall—

use data for the most recent year for which
				data are available; or

average data for the most recent 2- to
				3-year period for which data are available.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
that the school is one of the State's lowest-achieving
				schools for such year.

text.#text:
If a State determines that all schools that
				would otherwise be considered to be in the lowest-achieving 5 percent of
				schools under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
by the State to determine the most appropriate school improvement
				strategies to improve student performance. Such needs analysis shall
				include—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:1116/ss:i/p:2

text.#text:
Each local
				educational agency receiving assistance under this part shall conduct a
				data-driven needs analysis, which may involve an external partner with
				expertise in conducting such needs analysis, of each school identified under

a diagnostic review of data related to
				students and instructional staff;

an analysis of the school governance,
				curriculum, instruction, student supports, conditions for learning, and parent
				and family engagement practices relative to the needs of the student
				population; and

the resources, which may include
				community-based supports and early childhood education and care, available at
				the school, local educational agency, and community levels to meet student
				needs and support improved student achievement and outcomes and the
				implementation of any school improvement strategy.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
for each persistently low-achieving
				school in the State.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:1116/ss:i/p:5/sp:B

text.#text:
Each State receiving a grant under this
				part shall ensure that a local educational agency receiving assistance carries
				out the requirements of

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:1111
Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:1116/ss:i/p:2

text.#text:
Each local
				educational agency receiving assistance under this part shall, consistent with

text.#text:
establish a process for selecting an
				appropriate school improvement strategy for the school that uses information

develop a detailed budget covering the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:1116/ss:i/p:6

text.#text:
implement a school improvement strategy at
				the school in accordance with the requirements of

use appropriate measures to monitor the

review and select turnaround partners to
				assist in implementing school improvement strategies;

align other Federal, State, and local
				resources with the school improvement strategy;

provide the school with the operational
				flexibility, including autonomy over staffing, time, and budget, needed to
				enable full and effective implementation of the selected strategy, including
				through the modification of practices or policies, if necessary;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:1116/ss:i/p:2

text.#text:
take steps to sustain successful reforms
				and practices after the school is no longer identified under

provide technical assistance and other
				support to ensure effective implementation of the school improvement strategy
				in the school, which may include assistance in—
data collection and analysis;
recruiting and retaining staff;
teacher and principal evaluation;
professional development;
parent and family engagement;

coordination of services with early
				childhood education and care providers;

coordination of services to address
				students’ social, emotional, and health needs; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:1116/ss:i/p:6

text.#text:
monitoring the implementation of the school
				improvement strategy selected under

A State may take over
				a persistently low-achieving school and act as the local educational agency for
				purposes of this subsection, if permitted under State law.

A
				local educational agency implementing any strategies under this paragraph for a
				school shall—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:1116/ss:i/p:4

text.#text:
provide staff at the school with ongoing
				professional development, consistent with the needs analysis described in

provide time for collaboration among
				instructional staff at the school to improve student achievement;

provide instructional staff at the school
				with timely access to student data to inform instruction and meet the academic
				needs of individual students, which may include, in elementary school, school
				readiness data;

use data to identify and implement a
				research-based instructional program that—

analyzes student progress and performance
				and develops appropriate interventions for students who are not making adequate
				progress; and

provides differentiated instruction and
				related instructional supports;

in the case of an elementary school with
				kindergarten entry, consider the issue of school readiness in such school
				by—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:1116/ss:i/p:4

text.#text:
examining factors that contribute to school
				readiness as part of the needs analysis conducted under

if school readiness is identified in the
				needs analysis as an area in need of improvement—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Child Care Development and Block
				Grant Act of 1990
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Child Care Development and Block Grant Act of 1990

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, prekindergarten programs, and other
				similar Federal, State, and local programs, in order to align instruction to
				better prepare students for elementary school; and
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Head Start Act

text.#text:
coordinating with appropriate early
				childhood programs, such as programs under the

provide ongoing mechanisms for parent and
				family engagement; and

provide appropriate services and supports
				for students as identified in the school’s needs analysis.

header.#text:
Required activities for all school
				improvement strategies

text.#text:
A local educational agency shall identify a
				school improvement strategy for a school from among the following
				strategies:

if the principal
				has led the school for 2 or more years, replaces the principal with a new
				principal who has demonstrated effectiveness in turning around a low-performing
				school;

uses rigorous,
				transparent, and equitable evaluation systems to—

identify and
				reward school leaders, teachers, and other staff who, in implementing the
				model, increase student achievement and, if applicable, high school graduation
				rates; and

identify and
				remove school leaders, teachers, and other staff who, after ample opportunities
				have been provided for such individuals to improve their professional
				practice—

do not increase
				student achievement;

if applicable,
				do not increase high school graduation rates; and

provides staff
				with ongoing, high-quality, job-embedded professional development that is
				aligned with the school’s instructional program and evaluation system and
				facilitates effective teaching and learning, and supports the implementation of
				school-reform strategies;

implements
				strategies, such as financial incentives, increased opportunities for promotion
				and career growth, and more flexible work conditions that are designed to
				recruit, place, and retain staff with the skills necessary to meet the needs of
				the students in the school;

uses data to
				identify and implement a research-based instructional program that—

is
				aligned with State challenging academic content standards and challenging
				student academic achievement standards; and

establishes
				schedules and strategies that provide increased learning time, which may
				include offering full-day kindergarten or a high-quality preschool program or
				using a longer school day, week, or year that increases the total number of
				school hours for the school year at a school by not fewer than 300 hours to
				significantly increase the total number of school hours to include additional
				time for—

instruction in
				core academic subjects, instructions in such core academic subjects as,
				English, reading or language arts, mathematics, science, foreign languages,
				civics and government, economics, arts, history, and geography; and

instruction in
				other subjects and enrichment activities that contribute to a well-rounded
				education, such as physical education, service learning, and experiential and
				work-based learning opportunities that are provided by partnering, as
				appropriate, with other organizations;

promotes the
				continuous use of student data to provide instruction that meets the academic
				needs of individual students, which may include, in elementary school,
				individual students’ levels of school readiness;

establishes
				schedules and strategies that provide increased learning time, which may
				include expanding the school program to offer full-day kindergarten or a
				high-quality preschool program;

provides ongoing
				mechanisms for family and community engagement;

gives the school
				sufficient operational flexibility in programming, staffing, budgeting, and
				scheduling to fully implement a comprehensive strategy designed to
				substantially improve student achievement and, if applicable, increase the
				graduation rate;

ensures that the
				school receives ongoing, intensive technical assistance and related support
				from the local educational agency, the State educational agency, or a
				designated external lead partner organization; and

provides
				appropriate social-emotional and community-oriented services and supports for
				students and, at the discretion of the local educational agency, uses not more
				than 10 percent of the funds available for such school under this part to
				provide services to meet those needs.

A transformation model is one in which the local
				educational agency—

converts a school
				or closes and reopens the school—

under a charter
				school operator, a charter management organization, or an education management
				organization; or

as
				an autonomous or redesigned school;

implements a
				rigorous review process to select such a charter school operator, charter
				management organization, or education management organization, as applicable,
				which includes an assurance from such operator or organization that it will
				make significant changes in the leadership and staffing of the school;
				and

enrolls in the
				school, within the grades it serves, any former student who wishes to attend
				the school.

A restart model is one in which the local educational
				agency—

closes a school
				and enrolls the students who attended such school in other public schools
				served by the local educational agency that are higher performing, provided the
				other schools are within reasonable proximity to the closed school; and

provides
				information, in a timely fashion, in the appropriate language, and prior to
				closing the school, to children who attended such closed school and their
				parents, about high-quality educational options and transition and support
				services.

A school closure model is one in which the local
				educational agency—

if the principal
				has led the school for 2 or more years, replaces the principal with a new
				principal who has demonstrated effectiveness in turning around a low-performing
				school;

gives the new
				principal sufficient operational flexibility (including over staffing, the
				school day and school calendar, and budgeting) to fully implement a
				comprehensive approach to improve student outcomes;

using
				comprehensive evaluation systems, including the use of student achievement data
				to measure the effectiveness of staff who can work within the turnaround
				environment to meet the needs of students—

screens all
				existing staff and retains not more than 50 percent of such staff; and

provides staff
				with ongoing, high-quality, job-embedded professional development that is
				aligned with the school’s instructional program, facilitates effective teaching
				and learning, and supports the implementation of school-reform
				strategies;

adopts a new
				governance structure for the school, which may include requiring the school to
				report to a new turnaround office in the local educational agency or State
				educational agency, hire a turnaround leader who reports directly to the
				Superintendent or Chief Academic Officer, or enter into a multi-year agreement
				with the local educational agency or State educational agency to obtain added
				flexibility in exchange for greater accountability;

uses data to
				identify and implement a research-based instructional program and promotes the
				continuous use of data to evaluate school improvement strategies and to inform
				the differentiated instruction in order to meet the academic needs of
				individual students;

encourages the
				use of extended learning time partnerships;

establishes
				schedules and strategies that provide increased learning time, which may
				include offering full-day kindergarten or a high-quality preschool program or
				using a longer school day, week, or year that increases the total number of
				school hours for the school year at a school by not fewer than 300 hours to
				significantly increase the total number of school hours to include additional
				time for—

instruction in
				such core academic subjects as English, reading or language arts, mathematics,
				science, foreign languages, civics and government, economics, arts, history,
				and geography;

instruction in
				other subjects and enrichment activities that contribute to a well-rounded
				education, such as physical education, service learning, and experiential and
				work-based learning opportunities that are provided by partnering, as
				appropriate, with other organizations; and

provides ongoing
				mechanisms for family and community engagement;

provides
				appropriate social-emotional and community-oriented services and supports for
				students; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:1116/ss:i/p:6/sp:B/cl:i

text.#text:
may include any
				of the strategies described in

A turnaround model is one in which the local educational
				agency—

shall identify
				and address issues that may contribute to low academic achievement in those
				schools; and

may use funds
				under this subsection to provide comprehensive services to address those issues
				and meet the full range of student needs.

header.#text:
Using funds for
				comprehensive services To address issues

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:1116/ss:i/p:6/sp:B

text.#text:
In implementing any of
				the school intervention models described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:1116/ss:i/p:8

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may reserve not more
				than 10 percent to carry out activities of national significance, such
				as—

text.#text:
From the total
				amount appropriated under

building State
				and local educational agency turnaround capacity, including through technical
				assistance and support, identification and dissemination of best practices, and
				facilitating the creation and operation of communities of practice;

supporting the
				use of school quality review teams by making grants to State educational
				agencies, consortia of such agencies, or partnerships of State educational
				agencies or State consortia and public or private nonprofit organizations to
				develop and implement school quality review teams that review and provide
				support and technical assistance to local educational agencies and schools for
				activities such as expanded learning time;

identifying and
				disseminating effective rural turnaround practices, making available targeted
				technical assistance, and expanding the availability and capacity of turnaround
				partners that operate in rural areas;

identifying
				schools and school improvement partners that are effectively implementing
				school intervention models and other effective strategies to improve schools,
				and making information on those schools available to State educational
				agencies, local educational agencies, and schools in a manner that facilitates
				replication of effective practices; and

other activities
				designed to support State and local efforts to turn around persistently
				low-performing schools.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}fund.#text:
such sums as
				may be necessary for each of the 5 succeeding fiscal
				years
